text: Hi everybody, welcome to another episode on Mike Monticello.

Okay, so the first question today comes from Steve and Steve says,
lately, I've seen commercials advertising that their particular cars come recommended by CR.
I seem to recall that CR has a no advertising policy.
Do these ads fall under this policy or am I missing something?
Steve likely isn't the only person to have noticed this.
So, Jen, tell us about what's going on.
Yeah, so again, you've seen many of these ads and I think the placement has been so prevalent,
many, many top of, you know, when I say, in tournament sporting events, etc.
It was on during the Yellowstone Marathon that my husband was taking it.
So the people are absolutely seeing these ads, you know, with a lot of CR that they didn't see before.
So let me get back to Steve.
One, the no advertising policy still remains.
CR does not take advertising in the magazine on our website for manufacturers endorsing their own products.
That still remains.
We are still buying them at retail, just as consumers would.
All of that is still in place on the front end.
The difference is now that we are licensing the CR, what they call CR,

the CR recommendation products that get that recommended check mark or even some of the listings, you know, best brand overall or things like that top for reliability through what we call a reprints package.
And the impetus was to get that information where and when consumers are shopping.
So, you know, rather than having them go into a retail site and go, oh, now I got to go home and pull up CR that you would know added glance.

You know, this is a CR recommended product, maybe your in home depot, maybe your atlose, as well as let manufacturers use that advertising if you're in the market or even if you thought you might want to be in the market.
And the difference too is years and years ago, it wasn't quite as necessary.
There weren't so many reviews, endorsements, sponsored reviews that sometimes now you can't quite sort out.
Is this paid for? Is this even real?
Right.
And CR really wanted to be at the table as remaining that trusted mark, but differentiating ourselves.
I can tell you personally, the other benefit is we've had child seats in the past, just use that as an example.
The box says top rated by a leading consumer organization.
Right.
That was us.
We knew that was us, but we had no governance over that.
That child seat was long out of its top top ranked position. It was still on the box.
The other element of this is it's there's some rule here around it.
You have to be a CR recommended product to carry that logo with it.
So for you guys listening, you can have some assurance that that is a CR recommended product and that we're watching.
So it sounds like it's a win for us on the perspective that end consumers that we want our name out there when it's a good product and we want the consumers to know.
There is a little bit of money involved as well. Did you want to talk about that real quick just to be fully transparent?
Absolutely. We are collecting a fee for the use of that labeling for the use of the reprints.
The benefit is that money now goes back in. We are a non-profit organization.
Right.
Goes back in. Hopefully we're getting more Toyota Land Cruisers at 70K so that you can negotiate the market.
Meaning ability to buy more product to test.
It's not like that.
It's not like that.
Like raises or anything like that.
But it is a difference. You didn't see those before and now you're seeing them.
And I think the bigger thing is let me make it clear.
It does not change a thing for how and what we do here.
Looking strange.
It's all on the back end.
Only after a vehicle or any other product has gone through the process.
Can they then pick that up and use that recommendation?
So be assured.
